Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative - CS1: Creative Computation in the Context of Art and Visual Media

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing a new context for teaching introductory computing courses (CS1) using generative art and creative computation, focusing on multi-institutional adoption and diverse partnerships with high schools. This is a (re)-design and large-scale adoption effort of the CS1 course materials developed in a previous TUES-I project, supported by NSF DUE-0942626 and NSF DUE-0942628 (collaborative: Bryn Mawr College and Southern Methodist University). Two lead high school partners, James Martin High School (public, Dallas TX) and Sidwell Friends School (private, Washington, DC), are participating in the project by testing, adopting, and leading in the dissemination and adoption efforts among high schools nationally. An exemplar course is being developed that aligns with both CS AP A and CS Principles advanced placement initiatives. The project is working toward having the course adopted and formally assessed at a dozen participating colleges, universities and high schools nationwide.

This project integrates several facets of research and development: rethinking of introductory computing curricula and updating CS1 with contemporary, diverse examples of computing in a modern context; integrated components; context-driven text and teaching materials; formal assessment tools for evaluation; and community building in the educational domain. Evaluation is being done to assess potential improvement in student recruitment, retention and interest in computing as a result of a broader adoption of this new context, particularly of women and non-STEM or undecided majors, and of the viability of this model for the ongoing redesign of the AP CS course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our primary goal is to strengthen CS education overall and the introductory course (CS1) by providing students with a solid foundation in computing using the modern context of Creative Computation with Processing. We demonstrate that our Creative Computation curriculum can be successfully integrated into a variety of high school and undergraduate introductory courses.  We address the bridge between high school and entry-level college curriculum in computer science and demonstrate how algorithmic art provides a powerful vehicle for diverse student populations within a broad range of pedagogical frameworks ranging from traditional structured classrooms to inquiry-based student-driven project labs.

The following outcomes have been successfully achieved and exceeded:

  1. A complete set of course materials for both college-level and grades 10-12 that include lecture notes, presentation slides, class examples, lab exercises, problem sets, sample exams and quizzes. The curriculum aligns with a traditional ‘CS1’ approach as well as ‘AP CS A’, and goes well beyond ‘CS Principles’ standards to teach foundations of computer science and programming.
    1. The college-level course material repository can be found here:  https://www.cs.brynmawr.edu/gxk2013/ 
    2. High school course material catalog
    3. A textbook was developed and published in 2013
  2. A total of 29 offerings of CS1 courses at Bryn Mawr College (BMC) and Southern Methodist University (SMU) were offered during the three years 2013-2016 and reached a total of 600+ students (more than 50% women). The new CS1 has been successfully integrated in a sustainable manner into the computing curriculum at both lead institutions
  3. Multiple offerings of Level 3B courses at Martin High School (MFS) and Sidwell Friends School (SFS).
    1. MFS: Creative Computation was incorporated into all levels of computer science curriculum including Pre-AP Computer Science (CS0), AP Computer Science (CS1) and Advanced Computer Science III (CS2) and reached 400+ students (30% women in Pre-AP and AP CS)
    2. SFS: Creative Computation was integrated into all levels of computer science curriculum including Introduction to CS, Advanced CS, Artificial Intelligence and Game Design and reached 200+ students (female student participation improved from 16% to 32% to 50% in the final year)
  4. Minigrants and diverse partner institutions: Instructors from nine different institutions were awarded mini-grants and completed successful adaption and implementation of the Creative Computing curriculum in their own classrooms. Additionally, an external evaluator carried out assessment and data collection on all these courses. The curriculum was implemented at four high schools (2 public, 2 private), a public 2-year community college, a private 4-year liberal arts college and three 4-year universities (2 public, one private). One college course was offered online for both high school and college students. The four major regions, as defined by the US Census, were represented: one each in the Northeast and South (both high school), three in the West (two high school, one undergraduate) and four in the Midwest (four undergraduate, one on-line allowing high school student to register).

We also offered many opportunities for faculty training to increase adoption of the creative computation approach to CS1 in 4-yr college/universities and in high schools. The primary outcome here is to ensure that participating faculty and high school teachers are comfortable in adopting and implementing the creative computation focused CS1 courses.

  1. Two four-day summer faculty training workshop: Bryn Mawr 2014 and SMU 2015 (43 faculty attendees total)
  2. Two SIGCSE workshops held at both SIGCSE 2015 and SIGCSE 2016
  3. Four invited workshops
  4. 15+ adjunct faculty trained by the PIs and team leaders to teach the curriculum at their respective institutions

Lastly, we worked towards broader dissemination of materials in the CS education community. The grant has produced the following publications and products:

  1. Dianna Xu, Aaron Cadle, Darby Thompson, Ursula Wolz, Ira Greenberg, and Deepak Kumar. 2016. Creative Computation in High School. In Proceedings of the 47th ACM Technical Symposium on Computing Science Education (SIGCSE '16). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 273-278. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2839509.2844611
  2. Dianna Xu, Ira Greenberg, Deepak Kumar and Ursula Wolz. 2016. Creative Computation for CS1 and K9-12. In Proceedings of Envisioning the Future of Undergraduate STEM Education: Research and Practice Symposium (AAAS EnFuse). AAAS and NSF, Washington, DC, USA
  3. Dianna Xu, Ursula Wolz, Deepak Kumar and Ira Greenberg. 2018. Updating Introductory Computing Science with Creative Computation. In Proceedings of the 49th ACM Technical Symposium on Computing Science Education (SIGCSE '18). ACM, New York, NY, USA
  4. A web-portal for the grant found at https://www.cs.brynmawr.edu/visua/
  5. A college-level course material repository found at https://www.cs.brynmawr.edu/gxk2013/
